chapter: 3 Visualizing Data with a Grammar of Graphics
heading: 3.2 Plotting the diamonds dataset
text:
first plot going make use diamonds dataset ships plotnine.’ll import necessary stuff plotnine first.
seems like lot imports, made explicit can trace parts code come plotnine library.
code:
from plotnine import aes
from plotnine import facet_wrap
from plotnine import ggtitle
from plotnine import ggplot
from plotnine import geom_point
from plotnine import geom_bar
from plotnine import scale_color_brewer
from plotnine import theme_minimal
from plotnine import xlab
from plotnine import ylab
from plotnine.data import diamonds
import plotnine

plotnine.options.figure_size = (11, 8.5)

(
  ggplot(
    diamonds,
    aes(
      x = 'carat',
      y = 'price',
      color='clarity',
      size = "depth"
    )
  )
  + geom_point(alpha = 0.1)
  + scale_color_brewer(type='qual', palette=3)
  + facet_wrap('~color')
  + theme_minimal()
  + xlab("Carat")
  + ylab("Price ($USD)")
  + ggtitle('Diamond Prices by Carat')
)
#> <ggplot: (8740414110025)>

chapter: 3 Visualizing Data with a Grammar of Graphics
heading: 3.3 We can also run R
text:
, ’ll generate similar version plot just made Python, ’ll make one R.
’ll need different packages make work.look code plot, ask spot major differences Python version.Can spot differences?
code:
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(magrittr)
library(scales)

diamonds %>%
  ggplot(aes(carat, price, color = clarity, size = depth)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.1) +
  scale_color_brewer(type = 'qual', palette = 3) +
  facet_wrap(~ color) +
  theme_minimal() +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::dollar_format()) +
  labs(caption = "Example: Comparing the size, price, and clarity of 50,000 diamonds")

heading: 4.1 Pre-Class Assignment
text: Pick data-driven model.Posit structure model.parameters incorporated model?

heading: 4.2.1 Specify, Fit, Summarize
code:
import formulaic
import statsmodels.api as sm

import seaborn as sns

diamonds = sns.load_dataset("diamonds")

# Specify the model with a formula
y, X = formulaic.model_matrix("price ~ carat", diamonds)

# Fit the model
regression = sm.OLS(y, X).fit()

# Print the model summary
regression.summary()
